creator: bloch@clearwellsystems.com
text:
See the bottom of this report for an exception reported when asking the
1.4 JRE to check JNI stuff.  It comes in the middle of the log4j property
configurator which appears to running the code marked XXX below.
Seems strange to hit the problem there rather than 2 lines above
where the same kind of check is made against the String class.
I'm not really familiar with the Java language details but perhaps getClass()
is "safer" than .TYPE.  This could just be a JRE problem, too.

    String v = val.trim();
    if (String.class.isAssignableFrom(type)) {
      return val;
    } else if (Integer.TYPE.isAssignableFrom(type)) { //XXX
      return new Integer(v);
    } else if (Long.TYPE.isAssignableFrom(type)) {
      return new Long(v);
    } else if (Boolean.TYPE.isAssignableFrom(type)) {
      if ("true".equalsIgnoreCase(v)) {
        return Boolean.TRUE;
      } else if ("false".equalsIgnoreCase(v)) {
        return Boolean.FALSE; 

I don't know if this is a real issue or
not.  We're having problems with the JRE 1.4 server vm crashing and I 
want to rule out JNI problems.  I see this JNI "error" from both the server
and client VMs.

Below are the contents of the properties file that log4j is reading
 

#
# LPS Log4j properties

# LPS log
log4j.logger.com.laszlosystems=DEBUG, lps
log4j.appender.lps=org.apache.log4j.RollingFileAppender
log4j.appender.lps.File=${LPS_HOME}${file.separator}WEB-INF${file.separator}logs${file.separator}lps.log
log4j.appender.lps.MaxBackupIndex=5

log4j.appender.lps.layout=org.apache.log4j.PatternLayout
log4j.appender.lps.layout.ConversionPattern=%d{dd MMM yyyy HH:mm:ss} (%x) %-5p
%-20c{2} - %m%n

-Eric



% java -Xcheck:jni -Xfuture -ea -verbose -verbose:gc -verbose:jni \
    -verbose:class -esa -Xloggc:gc -Xrunhprof -server \
    -DLPS_HOME=C:\lps \
    -cp
